UAW PLAYS HAMLET ON TPP: Even as the AFL-CIO voices loud opposition to the Trans Pacific Partnership, the UAW (an AFL-CIO member union) is keeping a low profile on the issue. But as the trade deal nears completion the UAW confronts a difficult choice.
Story Continued Below
If it backs the deal, it will face a livid rank and file that's deeply skeptical of U.S. trade policy. But if it rejects it, that will rock the boat with an administration it's enjoyed close ties to. National political director Mary Beth Cahill worked as a consultant to Priorities USA Action, a Super PAC created to support Obama's re-election in 2012. Also, it was under President Barack Obama that the auto industry received an $80 billion bailout begun under President George W. Bush. 
The UAW has some substantive reasons to favor TPP, including its lengthy extension of protective tariffs. But the union is unhappy that the current deal doesn't address currency manipulation and weak labor rights in Mexico. After the agreement was largely finalized earlier this month, UAW President Dennis Williams issued a public statement warning that auto suppliers "might be faced with a flood of subsidized imports" and urged Froman to go back to the bargaining table. But for now, the UAW is staying neutral. More from Brian Mahoney here: http://politico.pro/1PwFl0I

NOW PUBLIC: CENTRAL STATES' PLAN TO CUT BENEFITS : The Central States Pension Fund’s application to cut vested benefits was posted Thursday to the Treasury Department’s website. Central States, one of the largest multiemployer pension plans in the country, filed the proposal September 25. The cuts come nearly one year after Congress enacted legislation that allows trustees for financially troubled multiemployer pension plans to cut benefits if they receive Treasury’s approval and if plan participants approve the cuts. Treasury can override a “no” vote, though, if a plan’s insolvency would cost the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation more than $1 billion--which the Central States plan is projected to do. 
Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle are still skeptical about the 2014 law. Last week, Sen. Rob Portman introduced bill that would prevent the Treasury Department from overriding a “no” vote. In June, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-VT) and Rep. Marcy Kaptur (D-OH) introduced legislation that would stop the cuts altogether and bail out insolvent multiemployer plans by closing two tax loopholes.
WHY DON’T WORKPLACE DISASTERS PUT CEOS IN JAIL?: Massey Energy CEO Don Blankenship is one of the few corporate executives to face possible jail time for the workplace deaths of his employees. But the specific charges against Blankenship -- arising from the deaths of 29 miners in 2010 -- don’t derive from mine safety statutes. Instead, International Business Times’ Cole Stangler writes, Blankenship has been charged “under general conspiracy statutes -- in effect, for defrauding the United States government. He faces two such felony counts: conspiracy to violate mining safety rules and conspiracy to block inspectors from carrying out their duties at the Upper Big Branch mine before the explosion. The other felony is for misleading financial regulators about his company’s safety record after the explosion.”
Why isn’t Blankenship being prosecuted for mine safety violations? Because those laws are fairly weak. “Workplace safety laws prescribe criminal charges under a narrow set of circumstances: Employers must willfully violate safety standards, give advanced notice of inspections, or make false statements. Then, the enforcement agencies -- in most cases, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), which covers most private sector workers, and the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) which covers mining workers -- have to recommend criminal prosecution to the Justice Department. The maximum penalty for these sorts of violations is a misdemeanor.”
OSHA Director David Michaels recently asked Congress to add criminal penalties to the OSH statute. “Simply put, OSHA penalties must be increased to provide a real disincentive for employers accepting injuries and worker deaths as a cost of doing business,” Michaels said. But given the GOP Congress we’re not likely to see tougher laws any time soon. http://bit.ly/1jECHK7
NLRB UPDATE 
BOARD MARVELS AT MCDONALD’S ‘CHUTZPAH’: The NLRB continued its long-standing discovery spat with McDonald’s in filings to Administrative Law Judge Lauren Esposito, who’s overseeing the agency’s joint employer case against the franchise. NLRB attorney Jamie Rucker asked Esposito to deny McDonald’s’ request that the trial in the case commence on Jan. 11. (Rucker doesn’t yet oppose that date but wants to reserve his right to ask for a continuance). 
As we noted earlier this week, the trial’s been held up as the NLRB seeks a federal court enforcement order requiring Mcdonald’s to comply with its voluminous discovery requests. McDonald’s said in earlier papers that it’s been stunned by the behavior of board lawyers, who are equally unimpressed with company lawyers. “In light of its behavior—and despite its claim to be ‘stunn[ed]’—it should be plain to McDonald’s why the General Counsel claims it is responsible for the fact that hearing has not resumed in this matter,” Rucker’s said. “The inescapable fact is that McDonald’s is responsible.” 
“McDonald’s’ attempt to attribute the delay in resuming hearing to the time it took for General Counsel to file enforcement papers is a particular brand of chutzpah,” Rucker added. “In essence, McDonald’s complains that the General Counsel is taking too long to force it to behave.” http://bit.ly/1G87DwS
Attached to its brief, the NLRB also appended a detailed May 22, 2014 memo from McDonald’s attorneys to the board’s division of advice on the applicability of the then-pending Browning-Ferris joint employer case to the charges at the heart of the McDonald’s case, as well as a general defense of the joint employer allegations. Read the memo here: http://bit.ly/1OFZzoj
NLRB DEFENDS UNION ELECTION RULE: The agency on Wednesday kicked off its defense of the new union election rule in the Fifth Circuit court of appeals. The board fended off a challenge from the Associated Builders and Contractors of Texas, which promptly appealed. Read the board’s brief here: http://bit.ly/1QypWeN
UNITE HERE ENDORSEMENT COULD COME IN JANUARY: The union and its powerful Nevada affiliate the Culinary Workers could decide to endorse just before the Nevada caucuses in February, according to the Los Angeles Times’ Kurtis Lee. The Culinary Workers and its largely Latino membership are an incredibly valuable bloc in the early primary state. “When you have a group of that size willing to put resources into a campaign, it’s powerful,” David Damore, an associate professor of political science at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, told the Times. “There is no need for a new mobilization effort of Latino voters here in Nevada,” he added. “What they have is consistent and will be there.” http://lat.ms/1LQaUNg
UNION PROPOSES TARGETED MINIMUM IN SACRAMENTO: UNITE HERE Local 49 filed a ballot measure in Sacramento that would raise the city’s minimum wage to $15 by 2019, but it would apply only to city lands. More from Sacramento Business Journal: http://bit.ly/1NeRYex
TEAMSTERS PRESS NMB ON ALLEGIANT BARGAINING: It’s been three years of contract deadlock between the Teamsters the low-budget airline Allegiant Air, and a strike is looming. Company pilots have already voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike, but the union must first exhaust its administrative remedies. Toward that end, Teamsters officials asked the National Mediation Board to release the union from ongoing negotiations with the airline. 
The NMB could decide to send the case to a third-party arbitrator. If that process fell through, the Teamsters could then strike after a 30-day cooling period. More from the A.P.: http://abcn.ws/1MFjJOX
CAN UBER DRIVERS STRIKE? Some Uber drivers are pushing for a strike this weekend. According to a Facebook events page, strike organizers are calling on Uber to raise rates by 60 percent nationwide, add tip options, raise the cancellation fee to $7, and raise the minimum fare to $7. The strike will test whether or not Uber drivers can successfully organize meaningful collective action, even though the company insists they are not employees.
